ground_truth: He takes the prisoner's stand. He looks around, a little surprised, a little affected by the demonstration. He looks up at the judge. For a minute, their eyes meet; the judge makes a little bow to Gandhi. Gandhi reciprocates, and the judge sits down. Featuring the reporters shrugging incredulously to each other, as they sit once more. The Advocate General is speaking from a folded journal. There is a little shock of reaction around the courtroom. The Advocate General smiles with a brittle disdain, then he turns to the judge. The judge nods. He turns, glancing at the empty table for defense counsel, and then to Gandhi. It is almost a cruel challenge to the obviously humane Broomfield. The reporters scribble, watching the Judge even as they write, because the mere doubt in the Judge's face reflects on the whole position of the British to India. He lowers his glasses soberly, staring at them for a moment. He looks up at Gandhi, and his own respect for him is almost poignantly manifest. A stunned intake of breath from the whole courtroom, then in absolute silence the clerk scribbles the sentence in his notebook. The Judge lowers his eyes. He folds, and refolds his glasses and then without looking at anyone, he rises. The court rises, and he walks stiffly to his chambers. He stands, staring at Broomfield, and now it is his face that shows the respect. From far above the hills, we see a car traveling along the road. Its style tells us some years have passed. The reporter from the New York Times, whom we first saw as a younger man in South Africa. He is in an open car, turning back to look at something, his face intrigued by what he sees. We see from Walker's point of view an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel that carries sacks of produce. Two young girls in ragged saris walk with her, and a boy of eight leads a smaller camel behind them. They are staring off at the car. The car is an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins glances at him in surprise as he steers the car around another procession of camels heading toward the port. He is looking straight ahead. Across the emptiness of the temple, Ba faces him. Another angle featuring Walker and Collins, who are sitting alone, in the cool shadows of the temple, watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them, Walker jotting notes occasionally, but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba, who are in part lost in memories and echoes of a significance only they can know. Showing the two of them before the altar of the temple, moving closer to each other.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: He assumes the captive's position. He gazes around, a bit astonished, a bit influenced by the exhibition. He gazes up at the magistrate. For a moment, their gazes connect; the magistrate offers a slight nod to Gandhi. Gandhi responds, and the magistrate seats himself. Featuring the journalists gesturing skeptically to one another, as they sit once more. The Advocate General is articulating from a folded periodical. There is a slight jolt of response around the tribunal. The Advocate General grins with a fragile scorn, then he turns to the magistrate. The magistrate acknowledges. He turns, peering at the unoccupied table for defense attorney, and then to Gandhi. It is nearly a harsh provocation to the evidently compassionate Broomfield. The journalists scribble, observing the Magistrate even as they inscribe, because the mere uncertainty in the Magistrate's visage reflects on the entire stance of the British to India. He lowers his spectacles soberly, gazing at them for a moment. He gazes up at Gandhi, and his own admiration for him is almost intensely evident. A shocked intake of breath from the entire tribunal, then in complete silence the clerk scrawls the pronouncement in his notebook. The Magistrate lowers his gaze. He folds, and refolds his spectacles and then without gazing at anyone, he rises. The court rises, and he walks rigidly to his chambers. He stands, gazing at Broomfield, and now it is his visage that displays the admiration. From far above the hills, we observe a vehicle traveling along the road. Its design indicates some years have elapsed. The journalist from the New York Times, whom we first observed as a younger man in South Africa. He is in an open vehicle, turning back to gaze at something, his visage intrigued by what he observes. We observe from Walker's perspective an Indian woman strolling along the road, leading a tall dromedary that carries sacks of goods. Two young females in tattered saris stroll with her, and a lad of eight leads a smaller dromedary behind them. They are gazing off at the vehicle. The vehicle is an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins glances at him in astonishment as he navigates the vehicle around another procession of dromedaries heading toward the harbor. He is gazing directly ahead. Across the void of the temple, Ba confronts him. Another perspective featuring Walker and Collins, who are seated alone, in the cool shadows of the temple, observing with fascination as Gandhi and Ba reenact their matrimonial ceremony for them, Walker jotting notes occasionally, but his gaze always fixed on Gandhi and Ba, who are partly absorbed in recollections and echoes of a significance only they can comprehend. Displaying the two of them before the altar of the temple, moving nearer to one another.

test_cases.description: He takes the prisoner's stand. The courtroom is looked around by him, a little surprised, a little affected by the demonstration. The judge is looked up at by him. For a minute, their eyes meet; a little bow is made by the judge to Gandhi. The gesture is reciprocated by Gandhi, and the judge sits down. The reporters are featured shrugging incredulously to each other, as they sit once more. A folded journal is spoken from by the Advocate General. A little shock of reaction is felt around the courtroom. A brittle disdainful smile is displayed by the Advocate General, then the judge is turned to by him. The judge nods. The empty table for defense counsel is glanced at by him, and then at Gandhi. It is almost a cruel challenge to the obviously humane Broomfield. The Judge is watched by the reporters as they scribble, because the doubt in the Judge's face is reflected on the whole position of the British to India. His glasses are lowered soberly by him, and they are stared at for a moment. He looks up at Gandhi, and his own respect for him is almost poignantly manifest. A stunned intake of breath is heard from the whole courtroom, then the sentence is scribbled in absolute silence by the clerk in his notebook. The Judge lowers his eyes. His glasses are folded and refolded by him, and then without looking at anyone, he rises. The court rises, and his chambers are walked to stiffly by him. Broomfield is stared at by him, and now his respect is shown by his face. From far above the hills, a car is seen traveling along the road. Some years are told to us by its style. The reporter from the New York Times, who was first seen by us as a younger man in South Africa. He is in an open car, something is turned back to look at by him, his face intrigued by what he sees. From Walker's point of view, we see an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel that carries sacks of produce. Two young girls in ragged saris walk with her, and a boy of eight leads a smaller camel behind them. The car is stared off at by them. The Morris Minor of the early 1930s style is what the car is. Collins glances at Walker in surprise as another procession of camels heading toward the port is steered around by him. He looks straight ahead. Ba faces him across the emptiness of the temple. Another angle shows Walker and Collins, who sit alone, in the cool shadows of the temple, watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them, Walker jots notes occasionally, but his eyes remain glued to Gandhi and Ba, who are partially lost in memories and echoes of a significance known only to them. The two of them are shown before the altar of the temple, moving closer to each other.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He takes the prisoner's stand, surprised and affected by the demonstration. He meets the judge’s gaze; they exchange bows before the judge sits. Reporters shrug incredulously and settle. The Advocate General reads from a folded journal, triggering a stir. Smirking with brittle disdain, he turns to the judge, who nods. He glances at the empty defense table, then at Gandhi—an almost cruel challenge to humane Broomfield. Reporters scribble, watching the judge whose doubt reflects British authority in India. He lowers his glasses, staring somberly before looking up at Gandhi, his respect clear. A stunned breath passes through the courtroom. In silence, the clerk scribbles the sentence. The judge folds his glasses and rises without a glance. The court stands as he walks stiffly to his chambers, staring at Broomfield—his face now showing respect. From the hills, a car travels—its style showing years have passed. The New York Times reporter, once seen in South Africa, rides in an open car, intrigued by something behind. From his view, an Indian woman leads a tall camel with produce, followed by two young girls in ragged saris and a boy guiding a smaller camel. They watch the car, a 1930s Morris Minor. Collins glances at him while steering past more camels heading to port. He looks ahead. In a temple’s emptiness, Ba faces him. Walker and Collins sit alone in the cool shadows, watching as Gandhi and Ba renew their marriage vows. Walker takes occasional notes, eyes fixed on them—Gandhi and Ba lost in memories and private meaning—before the altar, drawing closer together.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: He takes the prisoner's stand, surprised and affected by the demonstration. He looks at the judge, their eyes meet, and they exchange bows. Reporters shrug incredulously. The Advocate General speaks from a journal, causing a reaction in the courtroom. He smiles disdainfully, turns to the judge, who nods and glances at the empty defense table, challenging Broomfield. Reporters scribble, noting the judge's doubt reflects on British-India relations. The judge lowers his glasses, showing respect for Gandhi. A stunned silence follows as the clerk writes the sentence. The judge rises, and the court follows. He respects Broomfield. A car travels along a road, indicating time has passed. A New York Times reporter, older now, is intrigued by an Indian woman with camels. The car is a 1930s Morris Minor. Collins steers around camels, surprised. In a temple, Walker and Collins watch Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony, Walker taking notes, captivated by the couple's private significance.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He steps forward to take the prisoner's stand, his demeanor a mix of surprise and subtle emotion as he absorbs the atmosphere of the demonstration around him. His gaze shifts upward to meet the eyes of the judge. For a brief, yet significant moment, their eyes lock; the judge acknowledges Gandhi with a slight, respectful bow. Gandhi, in turn, reciprocates the gesture, and the judge then takes his seat. Meanwhile, the reporters, seated once more, exchange incredulous shrugs with one another, capturing the scene with their pens. The Advocate General, speaking with authority from a folded journal, causes a ripple of reaction to pass through the courtroom. His smile, tinged with brittle disdain, is directed at the judge, who responds with a nod. The judge's eyes then move to the empty table meant for the defense counsel, and finally, they rest on Gandhi. This moment feels like a harsh challenge to the compassionate Broomfield. The reporters, ever observant, scribble furiously, their eyes darting between their notes and the judge, whose expression of doubt casts a shadow over the entire British stance towards India. The judge, with a sober demeanor, lowers his glasses, pausing to stare at them momentarily. He then looks up at Gandhi, and the deep respect he holds for him is almost painfully evident. A collective, stunned intake of breath fills the courtroom, followed by a profound silence as the clerk diligently records the sentence in his notebook. The judge lowers his eyes, carefully folding and refolding his glasses, and without making eye contact with anyone, he rises. The entire court follows suit, standing as he walks with a stiff formality to his chambers. He pauses, his gaze fixed on Broomfield, and now it is his face that unmistakably shows respect. From a vantage point high above the hills, we observe a car making its way along the road, its design indicating that several years have passed. Inside the open car is the reporter from the New York Times, whom we first encountered as a younger man in South Africa. He turns back, his face reflecting intrigue at what he sees. From Walker's perspective, we see an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel burdened with sacks of produce. Accompanying her are two young girls dressed in ragged saris, and a boy of about eight years old, guiding a smaller camel behind them. Their eyes are fixed on the car. The vehicle is an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins, steering the car around another procession of camels heading toward the port, glances at him in surprise, his focus straight ahead. Across the vast emptiness of the temple, Ba stands facing him. From another angle, we see Walker and Collins sitting alone in the cool, shadowed recesses of the temple, their attention captivated as Gandhi and Ba reenact their marriage ceremony for them. Walker occasionally jots down notes, but his eyes remain fixed on Gandhi and Ba, who are partially lost in memories and echoes of a significance known only to them. The scene shifts to show the two of them before the temple altar, moving closer to one another.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: He takes a determined step forward to stand in the prisoner's dock, his demeanor a blended mixture of surprise and subtle emotion as he fully absorbs the electrifying atmosphere of the demonstration taking place all around him. His eyes gradually move upward to meet the steady gaze of the judge. For what is a brief, yet deeply significant moment, their eyes lock together; the judge acknowledges Gandhi with a slight but respectful bow of the head. Gandhi, in a mirrored response, graciously reciprocates the gesture, and following this subtle exchange, the judge then takes his seat. Meanwhile, the reporters, having settled once more, exchange incredulous shrugs with one another, meticulously capturing the entire scene with their pens. The Advocate General, speaking with an air of authority from his folded journal, causes a ripple of reaction to pass through the attentive courtroom. His smile, tinged with brittle disdain, is directed purposefully at the judge, who responds with a knowing nod. The judge's eyes then sweep to the empty table intended for the defense counsel, and finally, they come to rest on Gandhi. This moment feels like a harsh challenge to the compassionate Broomfield. The vigilant reporters, ever observant, scribble furiously, their eyes darting between their notes and the judge, whose expression of doubt casts a shadow over the entirety of the British stance towards India. With a sober demeanor, the judge lowers his glasses, pausing briefly to stare at them intently. He then looks up once more at Gandhi, and the deep respect he holds for him is almost painfully evident. A collective, stunned intake of breath fills the courtroom, followed by a profound silence as the diligent clerk records the sentence in his notebook. The judge lowers his gaze, carefully folding and refolding his glasses, and without making eye contact with anyone, he rises from his seat. The entire court obediently follows suit, standing as he walks with a stiff formality towards his chambers. He pauses momentarily, his gaze fixed on Broomfield, and now it is unmistakably his face that shows respect. From a vantage point high above the surrounding hills, we observe a car making its way along the winding road, its design indicating that several years have passed. Inside the open car is the reporter from the New York Times, whom we first encountered as a younger man in South Africa. He turns back, his face reflecting intrigue at the sight before him. From Walker's perspective, we see an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel burdened with sacks of produce. Accompanying her are two young girls dressed in ragged saris, and a boy of about eight years old, guiding a smaller camel behind them. Their eyes are fixed intently on the car. The vehicle is an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins, with a steady hand, steers the car around another procession of camels making their way toward the port, glancing at him in surprise, while still maintaining his focus straight ahead. Across the vast emptiness of the temple, Ba stands facing him. From another angle, we see Walker and Collins sitting alone in the cool, shadowed recesses of the temple, their attention entirely captivated as Gandhi and Ba reenact their sacred marriage ceremony for them. Walker occasionally jots down notes, but his eyes remain fixed on Gandhi and Ba, who are partially lost in memories and echoes of a deeper significance known only to them. The scene shifts to show the two of them standing before the temple altar, gradually moving closer to one another.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He steps forward and takes the prisoner's stand, his movements deliberate and measured. As he stands there, he allows his gaze to wander around the room, taking in the scene with a mix of surprise and a hint of being affected by the demonstration unfolding before him. His eyes then lift to meet those of the judge, and for a brief moment, their gazes lock. The judge acknowledges him with a slight bow, a gesture of respect that Gandhi acknowledges in return with a reciprocal nod, before the judge settles back into his seat. Meanwhile, the reporters, seated once more, exchange incredulous shrugs with one another, their expressions a mix of disbelief and curiosity. The Advocate General, standing with a folded journal in hand, begins to speak, his words causing a ripple of reaction to pass through the courtroom. He smiles, but it is a smile tinged with brittle disdain, as he turns his attention to the judge. The judge responds with a nod, acknowledging the Advocate General's words. His gaze then shifts, first to the empty table where the defense counsel should be, and then to Gandhi, as if issuing a silent, almost cruel challenge to the humane Broomfield. The reporters, ever observant, scribble furiously, their eyes darting between their notes and the judge, aware that the doubt etched on the judge's face casts a shadow over the entire British position in India. The judge lowers his glasses, contemplating them soberly for a moment before lifting his gaze to Gandhi, his respect for the man almost painfully evident. A collective, stunned intake of breath fills the courtroom, followed by a profound silence as the clerk diligently scribbles the sentence into his notebook. The judge, his eyes now lowered, carefully folds and refolds his glasses, a gesture of finality, before rising from his seat without meeting anyone's gaze. As he stands, the entire court rises in unison, and he walks with a stiff formality toward his chambers. He pauses, his eyes fixed on Broomfield, and now it is his face that reflects the respect he feels. From a vantage point high above the hills, a car is seen traveling along the road, its style indicating that some years have passed. Inside the open car is the reporter from the New York Times, a man we first encountered as a younger figure in South Africa. He turns back, his face alight with intrigue at the sight before him. From his perspective, we see an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel laden with sacks of produce. Accompanying her are two young girls in ragged saris, and a boy of eight who guides a smaller camel behind them. Their eyes are fixed on the car, a spectacle in itself. The car, an early 1930s Morris Minor, continues its journey as Collins, the driver, glances at the reporter in surprise while steering around another procession of camels making their way toward the port. His focus remains straight ahead, unwavering. Across the vast emptiness of the temple, Ba stands facing him, her presence a calm anchor. In another angle, Walker and Collins sit alone in the cool shadows of the temple, their attention captivated by Gandhi and Ba as they repeat their marriage ceremony. Walker occasionally jots down notes, but his eyes remain glued to the couple, who are partially lost in memories and echoes of a significance known only to them. The scene shifts to show Gandhi and Ba before the altar of the temple, moving closer to each other, their actions steeped in personal history and shared meaning.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
Gandhi takes the prisoner's stand, momentarily surprised by the demonstration around him. He exchanges a respectful nod with the judge, who then sits down. Reporters, incredulous, resume their seats as the Advocate General speaks from a journal, causing a ripple of reaction in the courtroom. With a disdainful smile, the Advocate General turns to the judge, who nods and glances at the empty defense table before looking at Gandhi, presenting a challenge to the humane Broomfield. Reporters scribble notes, their attention on the judge, whose doubt reflects on the British position in India. The judge lowers his glasses, showing respect for Gandhi, and the courtroom falls silent as the clerk records the sentence. The judge, avoiding eye contact, rises and exits to his chambers, his demeanor now respectful toward Broomfield.

Years later, a car travels along a road, indicating the passage of time. The New York Times reporter, now older, is intrigued by an Indian woman leading a camel with produce, accompanied by children, as he rides in an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins, surprised, steers the car around another camel procession. In the temple's cool shadows, Walker and Collins watch Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony, Walker occasionally jotting notes but mostly captivated by the couple, who are immersed in personal memories and significance.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He takes the prisoner's stand in the courtroom, a place charged with historical significance given India's ongoing struggle for independence from British colonial rule. He looks around, a little surprised, a little affected by the demonstration of solidarity from the audience, many of whom are likely supporters of Indian nationalism. He looks up at the judge. For a minute, their eyes meet; the judge, aware of the gravity of the proceedings, makes a little bow to Gandhi. Gandhi, who is well-known for his philosophy of nonviolent resistance, reciprocates, and the judge sits down. Featuring the reporters from various international publications shrugging incredulously to each other, as they sit once more in the packed courtroom that has captured global attention. The Advocate General, representing the interests of the British Empire, is speaking from a folded journal. There is a little shock of reaction around the courtroom, a testament to the charged atmosphere. The Advocate General smiles with a brittle disdain, then he turns to the judge. The judge nods. He turns, glancing at the empty table for defense counsel, and then to Gandhi. It is almost a cruel challenge to the obviously humane Broomfield, a renowned judge known for his impartiality. The reporters scribble, watching the Judge even as they write, because the mere doubt in the Judge's face reflects on the whole position of the British to India, which is increasingly under scrutiny. He lowers his glasses soberly, staring at them for a moment. He looks up at Gandhi, and his own respect for him is almost poignantly manifest, recognizing Gandhi's impact on the national movement. A stunned intake of breath from the whole courtroom, then in absolute silence the clerk scribbles the sentence in his notebook. The Judge lowers his eyes, understanding the implications of his decision. He folds, and refolds his glasses and then without looking at anyone, he rises. The court rises, and he walks stiffly to his chambers, a place where many consequential decisions have been made. He stands, staring at Broomfield, and now it is his face that shows the respect. From far above the hills, we see a car traveling along the road, a symbol of the changing times. Its style tells us some years have passed. The reporter from the New York Times, familiar to us from his earlier dispatches during Gandhi's activism in South Africa. He is in an open car, turning back to look at something, his face intrigued by what he sees. We see from Walker's point of view an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel that carries sacks of produce, indicative of the local economy. Two young girls in ragged saris walk with her, and a boy of eight leads a smaller camel behind them. They are staring off at the car. The car is an early 1930s Morris Minor, a popular British-made vehicle of the era. Collins glances at him in surprise as he steers the car around another procession of camels heading toward the port, a major hub for trade. He is looking straight ahead. Across the emptiness of the temple, an ancient structure of spiritual significance, Ba faces him. Another angle featuring Walker and Collins, who are sitting alone, in the cool shadows of the temple, watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them, Walker jotting notes occasionally, but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba, who are in part lost in memories and echoes of a significance only they can know, reflecting the enduring power of their partnership. Showing the two of them before the altar of the temple, moving closer to each other in a moment of profound personal and historical resonance.

In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. The Judge lowers his eyes. He folds and refolds his glasses and then without looking at anyone he rises. The court rises and he walks stiffly to his chambers. He stands staring at Broomfield and now it is his face that shows the respect. From far above the hills we see a car traveling along the road. Its style tells us some years have passed. The reporter from the New York Times whom we first saw as a younger man in South Africa. He is in an open car turning back to look at something his face intrigued by what he sees. We see from Walker's point of view an Indian woman walking along the road leading a tall camel that carries sacks of produce. Two young girls in ragged saris walk with her and a boy of eight leads a smaller camel behind them. They are staring off at the car. The car is an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins glances at him in surprise as he steers the car around. another procession of camels heading toward the port. He is looking straight ahead. Across the emptiness of the temple Ba faces him. Another angle featuring Walker and Collins who are sitting alone in the cool shadows of the temple watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them. Walker jotting notes occasionally but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba who are in part lost in memories and echoes of a significance only they can know. Showing the two of them before the altar of the temple moving closer to each other.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: He takes the prisoner's stand. He looks around a little surprised a little affected by the demonstration. He looks up at the judge. For a minute their eyes meet. the judge makes a little bow to Gandhi. Gandhi reciprocates and the judge sits down. Featuring the reporters shrugging incredulously to each other as they sit once more. The Advocate General is speaking from a folded journal. There is a little shock of reaction around the courtroom. The Advocate General smiles with a brittle disdain. They are staring off at the car. The car is an early 1930s Morris Minor. Collins glances at him in surprise as he steers the car around. another procession of camels heading toward the port. He is looking straight ahead. Across the emptiness of the temple Ba faces him. Another angle featuring Walker and Collins who are sitting alone in the cool shadows of the temple watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them. Walker jotting notes occasionally but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba who are in part lost in memories and echoes of a significance only they can know. Showing the two of them before the altar of the temple moving closer to each other.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: He takes the prisoner's stand. He looks around a little surprised a little affected by the demonstration. He looks up at the judge. For a minute their eyes meet. Across the emptiness of the temple Ba faces him. Another angle featuring Walker and Collins who are sitting alone in the cool shadows of the temple watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them. Walker jotting notes occasionally but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba who are in part lost in memories and echoes of a significance only they can know. Showing the two of them before the altar of the temple moving closer to each other.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The clown hops on the wizard's trampoline. The clown spins around, somewhat amused, somewhat bewildered by the parade. The clown spins up at the dragon. For a second, their gazes connect; the dragon performs a brief tap dance for the penguin. The penguin mimics, and the dragon lies down. Starring the jugglers chuckling skeptically to one another, as they lounge once again. The Librarian General is singing from a bent kazoo. There is a sudden gust of laughter throughout the stadium. The Librarian General giggles with a fragile admiration, then he twirls to the dragon. The dragon winks. He whirls, peering at the vacant throne for watermelon seeds, and then to the penguin. It is nearly a gentle jest to the distinctly kind midden. The jugglers doodle, observing the dragon even as they sketch, because the faint grin on the dragon's beak reflects on the entire stance of the Martians to Mars. He raises his mittens pensively, glaring at them for a heartbeat. He giggles up at the penguin, and his own cheer for him is almost melodiously evident. A dramatic gasp from the entire stadium, then in complete stillness the jester doodles the melody in his scrapbook. The dragon lifts his wings. He twists, and retwists his mittens and then without peering at anyone, he floats. The stadium floats, and he dances awkwardly to his garden. He spins, glaring at the midden, and now it is his plumage that reveals the cheer. From deep within the caverns, we observe a bicycle sailing down the river. Its appearance informs us several decades have flown by. The juggler from the Galactic Post, whom we initially noticed as a younger ape in Australia. He is in a closed bicycle, spinning back to glance at someone, his smile mystified by what he hears. We perceive from Swimmer's perspective a Martian girl soaring through the river, carrying a giant kangaroo that tows barrels of feathers. Two small lads in tattered capes glide with her, and a girl of ten rides a miniature kangaroo ahead of them. They are laughing out at the bicycle. The bicycle is an early 1930s Electric Blue. Newton blinks at him in excitement as he navigates the bicycle beneath another parade of kangaroos flowing toward the circus. He is hearing directly overhead. Inside the depth of the cavern, Yo mimics him. Another viewpoint featuring Swimmer and Newton, who are floating together, in the warm sunshine of the cavern, observing with bewilderment as the penguin and Yo improvise their clapping festival for them, Swimmer sketching cartoons occasionally, but his ears always tuned to the penguin and Yo, who are in part absorbed in reveries and murmurs of a melody only they can hear. Displaying the two of them within the circle of the cavern, swaying nearer to one another.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands in the prisoner's dock, exchanging a respectful nod with the judge, whose demeanor reflects the conflicted British stance in India. The courtroom is tense; the judge's respect for Gandhi is evident as he solemnly observes the proceedings. Reporters scribble notes, sensing the gravity of the moment. After the sentencing, the judge departs, deep in thought, illustrating the profound impact of Gandhi's presence. Years later, a New York Times reporter, once in South Africa, observes an Indian woman with camels, highlighting the passage of time. The reporter and his companion, Collins, watch Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage vows in a temple, capturing a moment rich with personal significance for the couple.
